CatDescriptText: Mrs. Elizabeth Simms, supermarket clerk, Terrace Village I and Mr. Bernard Spencer, singer, Sewickley, were part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, February 11, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "Do you favor legislation or voluntary (appealing to the souls and conscience of men) methods, like arbitration, mediation, persuasion, etc., to obtain civil rights for minorities?" Mrs. Elizabeth Simms' answer reads: "In a way, yes.  I don't think they should say 'Yes, sir,' 'No, sir', and so on.  I don't think it makes them feel exactly free.  And I think it's a dead issue, something of the past."  Mr. Bernard Spencer's answer reads: "I don't think this should be forced, but should come under their own power.  Many do this.  It's only an honest way of showing respect to their elders."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Elizabeth Simms wearing dark knit hat and leather gloves, standing in front of Brass Rail Restaurant, Smithfield Street, Downtown; Portrait of Bernard Spencer wearing dark fedora and moustache, standing in front of C.C.Mellor Co., Smithfield Street, Downtown
